transcripts.text: This is a rule of VAT and this is a rule that was very, very clear that it was something that was outside the government's control.  So having a campaign on it was all very well, but the EU refused to change the rules and therefore it had to continue.  It was only once we left the EU that we were able to actually see that tax abolished.

Well, during the referendum, actually, David Cameron went to the EU and the EU decided they would change their laws.  So now from 2022, any member of state can act upon tax if they want to.  So really, Brexit has only made less than a year's difference.  And it also is a tax that will be affected by anyone who has a period, but also anyone who buys them.
What do you mean?  anyone who has a period?  So you mean women and girls?
So I just mean anyone who has a uterus.

Not all women and girls.  Well, no, not all women.  You know, people who are postmenopausal, people, you know, women, women under the age.  So women and girls.  We're not saying people who have periods on my show.  We're saying women and girls.
Okay, well...
No, genuinely, I won't have you on the show if you're going to talk that nonsense.  Men don't have periods.  Full stop.  Women and girls.
Okay, well, I think that's quite transphobic, but...
You think that's quite transphobic.  Do you know any men who have periods, Laura?
I do actually know quite a lot of trans activists.
Do you know any men who have periods?
I know... Yes, I do.  You do?  I think trans men are men.
I think they're lying to you, love.
No, I don't agree with that.
You don't agree with that?  You think men who don't have uteruses, you think men have periods, do you?
Yes, because some men have uteruses.
Some men have uteruses.  How do those men have uteruses if they're not born women?
If they identify as a man and yet they have a uterus, then they're a man with a uterus.

You can identify with whatever you want, but only women and girls have periods, don't they?  That's a biological fact.  I think that's in all the medical books, I think.  I'm pretty sure.  Okay, well, I don't think that conversation is necessarily helpful.
No, but I do.

Well, it is.  I mean, again, let's talk about something sensible.  So you wanted the tampon tax.  What I've never understood about this, and I've written about this in the past, is why people got so obsessed with this.  There are lots of products that have VAT on them.  Again, e-books.  When I bought a car seat for my daughter when she was a baby, there was VAT on that.  Why did we have such an issue?  Why did people have such an issue about VAT on this one particular product?

I think because it's such an example of sexism and just an example of the fact that people who have periods in the decision-making rooms, there are very few women, especially when the tax was introduced in 1973, only 4.3% were women.  And so people felt like they shouldn't talk about the whole topic of periods.  And so it's more than just a tax on this.  It's also about period poverty.  It's also about period education.  and the fact that so many girls across the country are missing school because of this period.
We're told this all the time, but there's very little evidence for these statements.

There is actually evidence.  Plan International UK has done a huge study over the years, and they have found that 10% of schoolgirls in the UK miss school because they don't have access to period products, and they feel like they can't ask for them.
What do you mean?  they don't have access to period products?  They can't go to Superdrug or Boots?  You're saying they can't afford them?  You're saying their parents aren't giving them to them?

Yes, 10% of schoolgirls literally come from families that cannot afford them.  They perhaps have lots of siblings or they're in the 4 million kids in this country that are in poverty and they cannot afford them every single month.  But there's a wider statistic that says that 49% of schoolgirls have missed at least a day of school every year because they're embarrassed about their periods.
That's got nothing to do with tampon tax though, has it?
It's got a lot to do with period stigma though and period shame, which is also attached to the tampon tax and why it's been going on for so long.
Because people didn't want to talk about it.  I have to say, I don't, I mean, I'm 51.  I don't even remember there being a stigma about periods even when I was young.
Well, I mean...
Where's this come from?

I think it's happened forever.  Even when it comes to just the terminology that we use, like time of the month or like all of these other words that make us not be able to say the word period.  Even the period adverts that we've had.  that's like, please keep it discreet, have these little tins that you can put your... period products in and nobody will know.  or the blue liquid that kind of makes it seem not realistic on TV or even the words like sanitary products or feminine hygiene makes us seem unhygienic on our period.
Well we can't call it feminine hygiene anymore can we?  because men are having periods now.
It's just all of these words that are laced in this book.

All right, then.  Laura Corrigan, thank you very much.  Well, you had a successful campaign there.  Stop taxing periods campaign.  Again, I'm more of a priority about not.  I mean, we tax a lot of products which are necessities, I say, including car seats.  VAT is on an awful lot of stuff that we do consider to be vital.  Anyway, let's turn our attention to other aspects in the budget.  That's obviously a very small aspect.  In fact, tampon tax.  I think I worked out when I did the maths on an average girl.  Again, some people will have heavier periods and use more products any month.  The average woman will be spending 75 pence a year on the tax that they're paying, the VAT they're paying on their sanitary products.  I'm not sure it's that big a win for women, but there we are.
